turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Tanks in the Italian Army.
turn.1: What happened to the Carro Armato M16/43?
turn.2: The Carro Armato M16/43 was cancelled before the single prototype was completed after Axis were expelled from North Africa so never was used in the war.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In September 1943, Italy made an armistice with the Allies and split into the Italian Social Republic - effectively a puppet state of Germany - in the north and that of the Badoglio government in the south.
turn.5: What happend after they made an armistice?
turn.6: The Italian Co-Belligerent Army ("Esercito Cobelligerante Italiano") was the army of the Italian royalist forces fighting on the side of the Allies in southern Italy after the Allied armistice with Italy in September 1943.
turn.7: What other weapons did they use?
turn.8: The Carro Armato P40 came late in the war and was armed with a 75 mm gun and an 8 mm Breda machine gun, plus another optional machine gun in an anti-aircraft mount.
turn.9: What else was known about the M16/43?
turn.10: Of the 1,200 tanks ordered, only a few (between one and five depending on the source) pre-production models were completed before the Italian Armistice in September 1943, at which point they were taken over by the German Wehrmacht.
turn.12: About a hundred P40s were built by Ansaldo from then until the end of the war, although most were not entirely completed because of a lack of engines.
